statement:
Let $(X,d)$ be a complete metric space. A function $T:X \to X$ is said
to be a *contraction mapping* if there is a constant $q$ with
$0 \leq q < 1$ such that $$d(Tx,Ty)\leq q\cdot d(x,y)$$ for all
$x,y\in X$. Contractions have an important property.

Every contraction has a unique .

There is an estimate to this fixed point that can be useful in
applications. Let $T$ be a contraction mapping on $(X,d)$ with constant
$q$ and unique fixed point $x^* \in X$. For any $x_0 \in X$, define
recursively the following sequence $$\begin{aligned}
  x_1      &:=& Tx_0   \\
  x_2      &:=& Tx_1   \\
         &\vdots&      \\
  x_{n+1}  &:=& Tx_n.\end{aligned}$$ The following inequality then
holds: $$d(x^*,x_n)\leq \frac{q^n}{1-q}d(x_1,x_0).$$ So the sequence
$(x_n)$ converges to $x^*$. This estimate is occasionally responsible
for this result being known as *the method of successive
approximations*.
